questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neglect

 

Neglect after a stroke, often presenting as a lack of awareness of one side of the body, does not typically require direct medical treatment. While it may indicate a more severe stroke and can impact rehabilitation, many patients improve as they recover from other stroke symptoms. Therapy focuses on aiding patients in adapting to or compensating for this deficit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia: Must be treated to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option B. Spasticity: Requires management with medications (baclofen, tizanidine) or physical therapy to improve mobility and reduce discomfort.

 

Option C. Fever: Should be treated promptly as it can exacerbate brain injury and worsen outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While neglect is a common symptom following a stroke, it does not typically require specific medical treatment but rather supportive care and rehabilitation to help the patient adapt. Other physical symptoms such as dysphagia, spasticity, and fever require active medical management to prevent complications.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET  PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhaled anesthetic agent for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients. This is primarily due to its pleasant, sweet smell, which makes it more tolerable for children to inhale. Additionally, Sevoflurane has a rapid onset of action, meaning it works quickly to induce anesthesia. This quick induction is critical in pediatric patients who often do not have an intravenous (IV) line placed before induction. The ability to induce anesthesia effectively and without distress is a significant advantage in this age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is not preferred for pediatric induction because it has a pungent odor, which can be irritating and unpleasant for children. Moreover, it can cause airway irritation, which is undesirable during induction.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: While Isoflurane is effective as an anesthetic, it also has a pungent smell and slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential for causing liver toxicity and its slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:


Sevoflurane is the anesthetic agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its sweet smell and rapid onset of action.

choices.text: Amphotericin B

questions.text: For which of the following drugs, absorption is increased after a fatty meal? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Griseofulvin

 

Griseofulvin is an antifungal drug that acts by blocking the microtubules. It is given orally, preferably with a fatty meal, which has been found to increase its absorption. This enhancement in absorption is due to the lipophilic nature of griseofulvin, which allows it to dissolve better in the presence of dietary fats, facilitating its uptake in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication primarily administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. Its absorption is not significantly affected by meals.

 

Option C. Ampicillin: Ampicillin is an antibiotic that is generally well absorbed on an empty stomach. Food can actually reduce the absorption of ampicillin.

 

Option D. Aspirin: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory and antipyretic drug. Its absorption is not significantly increased by fatty meals, although taking it with food can help minimize gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs whose absorption increase with meals

Griseofulvin

Statins

Halofantrine

Erlotinib

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenomas are not seen in MEN 2B. Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, where hyperparathyroidism is a common feature due to the involvement of the parathyroid glands.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by specific clinical features. It is also known as the "Triple M syndrome" because it typically presents with the following:

 

  • Mucosal Neuromas: These are benign growths on the mucous membranes and are a hallmark of MEN 2B.
  • Marfanoid Habitus: This refers to a body habitus resembling Marfan syndrome, with features like long limbs, a tall, slender build, and hyperflexible joints.
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a type of thyroid cancer commonly associated with MEN 2B.

 

Other features that can be seen in MEN 2B include pheochromocytomas (tumors of the adrenal glands) and ganglioneuromas (tumors of the nerve cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Megacolon: Megacolon can be associated with MEN 2B due to the presence of ganglioneuromatosis affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Mucosal Neuroma: As mentioned, mucosal neuromas are a classic feature of MEN 2B and one of the reasons it is called "triple M syndrome."

 

Option D. Marfanoid Habitus: This characteristic physical appearance is commonly seen in MEN 2B patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

choices.text: Deletion of gene

questions.text: A case of complete gonadal dysgenesis was observed in a 46XY individual with female characteristics. The origin of complete gonadal dysgenesis lies in alterations of the SRY gene. What leads to complete gonadal dysgenesis in the SRY gene? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deletion of gene

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is typically associated with alterations in the SRY gene, which is crucial for initiating male sex determination. The SRY gene, located on the Y chromosome, directs the development of the gonads into testes. When this gene is deleted, it results in a failure to initiate testis formation, leading to a phenotypically female individual with a 46XY karyotype. In 10-15% of cases of 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, the SRY gene deletion is the underlying cause. This leads to a failure in developing male characteristics and results in complete gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point mutation: Point mutations in the SRY gene can also lead to gonadal dysgenesis, but this accounts for only a small percentage of cases. The mutations typically involve changes in the DNA sequence that alter the function of the SRY protein but do not necessarily delete the gene.

 

Option C. Translocation: Translocation refers to the movement of the SRY gene to another chromosome, which can sometimes lead to sex reversal if the SRY gene is present on an X chromosome in a 46XX individual. However, this is not the primary mechanism for complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual.

 

Option D. Inversion: Inversions involve a segment of the chromosome being reversed end to end. This type of chromosomal rearrangement is less commonly associated with gonadal dysgenesis and is not a typical cause of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is primarily caused by the deletion of the SRY gene, which leads to a failure in the development of male gonads, resulting in female characteristics.

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased fibrinogen

 

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a complex condition characterized by systemic activation of blood clotting, which results in the generation and deposition of fibrin, leading to microvascular thrombi in various organs and contributing to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. As a part of this process, there is widespread consumption of clotting factors and platelets, which leads to a paradoxical increase in bleeding risk.

 

  • Increased fibrinogen is incorrect because in DIC, fibrinogen is typically decreased, not increased. This decrease is due to its consumption during the formation of fibrin clots throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% of patients w/DIC may have schistocytes on PS.

 

Option B. Consumption of clotting factors leads to ↑PT, aPTT. Presence of normal PT, aPTT w/schistocytes hints towards possibility of MAHA.

 

Option D. FDP are elevated due to activation of coagulation cascade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DIC, one typically sees a constellation of laboratory findings including decreased fibrinogen, increased PT and aPTT, elevated FDPs, and the presence of schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. These changes reflect both the excessive activation of the coagulation cascade and the secondary activation of fibrinolytic pathways, leading to the consumption of clotting factors and secondary bleeding complications.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hematology/Coagulation disorders

questions.text: A child was being delivered oxygen by nasal canula at 3L/min. What is the FiO2 being delivered?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  30%

 

Explanation:

 

The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered by nasal cannula increases by approximately 4% for every 1 liter per minute of oxygen flow. Thus:

 

  • 1 L/min would raise the FiO2 to about 24%.
  • 2 L/min would be about 28%.
  • 3 L/min would be about 32%.

 

Given the options provided, the closest and most commonly accepted approximation for the FiO2 being delivered at a flow rate of 3 L/min through a nasal cannula would be around 30%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 1 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option C. 40%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 5 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option D. 45%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 6 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FiO2 delivered by a nasal cannula at a flow rate of 3 L/min is approximately 30%.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prodrug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Primidone

 

  • Prodrugs are drugs that are present in their inactive form and are converted to the active form in the body after undergoing metabolism.
  • Among the given options primidone is not a prodrug. Although it produces active metabolites like phenobarbitone and phenylethylmalonamide (PEMA) but it cannot be considered as a prodrug because primidone itself is also active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proguanil: Proguanil is a prodrug and its active metabolite is cycloguanil. It is used in the treatment and prevention of malaria.

 

Option C. Sulindac: Sulindac is a sulfoxide prodrug used in inflammatory diseases including osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Option D. Flurouracil: Flurouracil  is a prodrug having the active metabolite as fluorouridine monophosphate. It is an anticancer chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primidone is not a prodrug because it is pharmacologically active in its original form, although it also produces active metabolites. Prodrugs like Proguanil, Sulindac, and 5-Fluorouracil require metabolic activation to exert their therapeutic effects.

 

Mnemonic

questions.text: Which among the following monitors is most commonly used to monitor the depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bispectral index

 

  • The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used method to monitor the depth of anesthesia and determine the level of consciousness under anesthesia.
  • BIS is derived from the EEG (electroencephalogram) and shows the cerebral drug effect of an anesthetic drug.
  • BIS values range from 0-100, where lower values indicate deeper anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EEG: While EEG is the basis for BIS, it is not typically used directly in clinical practice to monitor anesthesia depth due to its complexity.

 

Option B. Provoked lower esophageal contractility: This is not a standard or common method for monitoring the depth of anesthesia.

 

Option C. Entropy: Entropy monitoring is another EEG-based technique used to assess the depth of anesthesia. However, it is less commonly used compared to BIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used monitor to assess the depth of anesthesia, providing an EEG-derived measure of the cerebral effects of anesthetic drugs.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are caused by high-risk strains of Human Papilloma virus except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papillomatosis

 

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is not caused by high-risk HPV strains but by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: Caused by high-risk HPV strains, particularly HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. Anal carcinoma: Also associated with high-risk HPV strains, including HPV 16.

 

Option C. Oropharyngeal carcinoma: Linked to high-risk HPV strains, notably HPV 16.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11) and not by the high-risk strains associated with cancers such as cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 563

questions.text: Which of the following is an immunologically privileged site? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminiferous tubule

 

The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site.

 

Sites with immune privilege are anatomical regions that are naturally less subject to immune responses than most other areas of the body. So, an allograft can be placed in these sites without endangering a rejection reaction.

 

Other examples:

 

  • Anterior chamber of the eye
  • Cornea
  • Testes
  • Brain except at area postrema where blood brain barrier is absent

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Area postrema: This region of the brain lacks the blood-brain barrier and is not considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Option C. Optic nerve: While the optic nerve is part of the central nervous system, it is not classified as an immunologically privileged site like the brain or anterior chamber of the eye.

 

Option D. Loop of Henle: This structure is part of the kidney's nephron and is not considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Educational Objective:


The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site, protecting developing sperm from immune system attack.

questions.text: Which of the following represents maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a test that measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as it clots under low shear conditions, mimicking sluggish venous flow. The maximum amplitude (MA) on a TEG tracing represents the final strength of the clot and is predominantly determined by the number and function of platelets and fibrin interaction.

 

  • Platelets play a crucial role in forming the solid clot structure, which is reflected by the MA. Thus, the maximum amplitude in TEG is directly associated with platelet function and quantity.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic and Option C. Extrinsic: These terms refer to different pathways of the coagulation cascade, not directly to the maximum amplitude in TEG.

 

Option D. vWD: von Willebrand Disease affects platelet adhesion due to deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, but the maximum amplitude is a function of platelet interaction with fibrin, not directly of vWD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography represents platelets. TEG is a non-invasive test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with no significant past medical history is scheduled for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the preoperative discussion, the anesthesiologist explains the plan for anesthesia induction, emphasizing the importance of a rapid onset with smooth, controlled sedation. The patient expresses concern about feeling nauseous after waking up, and the anesthesiologist mentions using an agent that minimizes such risks and ensures a quick recovery. Which of the following agents is commonly used for intravenous induction of anesthesia in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Propofol

 

Explanation:

 

Propofol is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent commonly used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. It has a rapid onset of action, usually within 30 seconds, and provides a smooth, rapid recovery, making it highly effective for outpatient and short surgical procedures. Propofol is known for its antiemetic properties, reducing postoperative nausea and vomiting, and is often preferred for patients concerned about these side effects. However, it can cause dose-dependent hypotension and respiratory depression, requiring careful monitoring during administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Etomidate: Etomidate is another intravenous induction agent known for its minimal cardiovascular effects, making it suitable for patients with compromised cardiac function. However, it is not typically used as the first-line agent due to its association with adrenal suppression and increased risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting, unlike propofol.

 

Option B. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that provides analgesia, sedation, and amnesia with minimal respiratory depression. It is particularly useful in trauma patients or those with risk of hypotension, but it is not commonly used for routine anesthesia induction due to its psychomimetic effects, such as vivid dreams and hallucinations during recovery.

 

Option D. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine used primarily for premedication and procedural sedation, not as a primary induction agent. It has anxiolytic, amnesic, and sedative properties but lacks the rapid onset and recovery profile of propofol, making it unsuitable for the induction of general anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is widely used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia due to its rapid onset, smooth induction, and quick recovery profile. It minimizes postoperative nausea and vomiting, though it requires careful monitoring for potential hypotension and respiratory depression. Other agents like etomidate, ketamine, and midazolam have specific uses but do not match propofol's overall safety and efficacy for routine induction.

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPR with 20% intralipid

 

  • The scenario described involves a young male patient who received a regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure and subsequently became unresponsive with an unrecordable pulse.
  •  These are concerning signs of Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST), which can occur when local anesthetic drugs like bupivacaine enter the systemic circulation.
  • The best course of management for this patient is as follows:
  • This is the correct choice. Intralipid is a lipid emulsion used as the antidote for LAST.
  • It works by sequestering the local anesthetic drug in the lipid phase and reducing its toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  •  CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) should be initiated, and 20% intralipid should be administered intravenously to treat LAST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CPR with sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is not the first-line treatment for LAST. While it can be used to treat certain cardiac arrhythmias caused by local anesthetic toxicity, it does not directly counteract the toxic effects on the central nervous system and is not as effective as intralipid.

 

Option C. CPR with dobutamine: Dobutamine is a medication used to increase cardiac output and blood pressure in some situations, but it is not the primary treatment for LAST.

 

Option D. CPR with calcium: Calcium does not reverse the toxic effects of local anesthetic systemic toxicity. Therefore, it is not the appropriate treatment for this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient experiences LAST with signs of cardiovascular collapse and central nervous system toxicity, the recommended treatment is CPR (if necessary) along with the administration of 20% intralipid intravenously, as it helps to reverse the toxic effects of the local anesthetic and improve the patient's condition.
  • Drug of choice for treatment of LAST – 20% Intralipid IV

choices.text: Increase flow rate to 15 L/min
High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but his respiratory rate is 26/min. Room air Sp02 is 86%. He is administered oxygen through a non -rebreathing mask with a flow rate of 10 L/ min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

 

  • Mechanism of Action: HFNC can deliver warmed, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min or more), creating a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) effect, reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, and improving oxygenation.
  • Effectiveness: Studies have shown its effectiveness in treating acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in COVID-19 patients. Given that the patient's SpO2 didn't improve significantly with an NRB, transitioning to HFNC might be a logical step before considering more invasive measures like intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase flow rate to 15 L/min: The non-rebreather mask (NRB) is designed to deliver high concentrations of oxygen (up to 90%). Increasing the flow rate may slightly improve the fraction of delivered oxygen, but it may not result in significant improvement in oxygenation, especially if the cause of hypoxia isn't just a low FiO2. Therefore, merely increasing the flow rate may not be sufficient to address the patient's respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are invasive interventions, reserved for patients who are in respiratory failure and cannot maintain adequate oxygenation and/or ventilation with less invasive means. While this patient is hypoxic, jumping straight to intubation without trialing intermediate steps like HFNC might be premature, especially since the patient is alert and responsive.

 

Option D. No specific intervention necessary: Given the patient's low SpO2 and increased respiratory rate, no intervention is not an appropriate choice. The patient is in respiratory distress and requires further measures to improve his oxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with COVID-19 and hypoxemia unresponsive to a non-rebreather mask, transitioning to high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) is a logical next step. HFNC can provide better oxygenation and is a less invasive option before considering endotracheal intubation.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Automated External Defibrillator

 

Explanation:

 

Automated External Defibrillator (AED):

 

  • Definition: An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device that automatically diagnoses the life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia, and is able to treat them through defibrillation, the application of electricity which stops the arrhythmia, allowing the heart to re-establish an effective rhythm.

 

  • Rapid Defibrillation: Rapid defibrillation is paramount in improving survival rates from sudden cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

 

  • User-Friendly and Accessible: AEDs are made for laypersons and first responders, not just for medical professionals. They come with voice prompts and sometimes visual displays to guide the user through each step of the defibrillation process. This design makes it possible for people without extensive medical training to assist in a cardiac emergency.

 

  • Self-Analyzing: An AED automatically evaluates the heart rhythm of a person in cardiac arrest. If the device detects a shockable rhythm, it will instruct the user to deliver a shock; if not, it will guide the user to continue with CPR or other appropriate interventions. This ensures that shocks are only given when necessary.

 

  • Public Availability: Many public places such as airports, gyms, schools, and shopping centers have publicly accessible AEDs. Increasing the availability and visibility of AEDs in public spaces can reduce the time to defibrillation and increase survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Automated External Desynchronizer: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Option C. Automated Electronic Defibrillator: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Option D. Automated External Decompressor: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is a crucial device for rapidly diagnosing and treating life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias through defibrillation, especially designed for use by laypersons and first responders to increase survival rates in cases of sudden cardiac arrest.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2537

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

 

Explanation:

 

The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.

 

Option B. 15 L/min: This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.

 

Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: Addison's disease is commonly associated with: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autoimmune adrenalitis

 

Addison's disease, primarily characterized by adrenal insufficiency, is most commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis. In this condition, the body's immune system attacks the adrenal cortex, leading to a decrease in the production of steroid hormones such as cortisol and aldosterone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypernephroma: Also known as renal cell carcinoma, hypernephroma is a type of kidney cancer and has no direct link to the adrenal function or Addison's disease.

 

Option C. Adrenocortical carcinoma: This is a cancer of the adrenal cortex but typically leads to excessive hormone production, associated more with Cushing's syndrome rather than Addison's disease, where there is hormone deficiency.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid: This type of cancer is associated with the thyroid gland and is related to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndrome but not directly linked to Addison's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis, where the immune system mistakenly attacks the adrenal glands, leading to insufficient production of vital hormones.

questions.text:
The following are true about chancroid: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. School of fish appearance
  2. Bleeds on touch
  3. Painful
  4. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B, & C

 

Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Hemophilus ducreyi and results in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.

 

H. ducreyi is a small, fastidious gram-negative rod that requires an enriched growth medium cultivated in a high humidity, CO2-enriched environment. On Gram stain, long strands of organisms are seen in a pattern often referred to as a "school of fish" or "railroad track" in appearance.

 

Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a "soft chancre." Multiple ulcers may be noted either as a result of multiple areas of microtrauma or as a result of direct contact between two adjacent areas resulting in "kissing ulcers." The ulcer typically has a friable base with yellow-gray exudate, which easily bleeds when abraded and varies in size, typically from 1 to 2 cm. Left untreated, the lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months.

 

Other Option:


D. Groove sign: This is typically associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and not chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, is characterized by painful ulcers with a friable base that easily bleeds and has a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain. The "groove sign" is not associated with chancroid but rather with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

questions.text: A patient is given a nicotinic receptor antagonist as a muscle relaxant. Which drug is given postoperatively to recover from muscle weakness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neostigmine

 

For reversal of neuromuscular blockade from non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, the reversal agent of choice is Neostigmine.

 

  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that boosts the concentration of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, thus enhancing muscle contraction.
  • Neostigmine is the drug of choice for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively. By preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine, it counteracts the muscle-relaxing effects of these drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine:

 

  • Physostigmine is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor. It increases the concentration of acetylcholine at nerve endings.
  • Physostigmine is primarily used to treat anticholinergic (atropine-like) drug overdoses. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and is used for central anticholinergic syndromes. It is not typically used for reversing neuromuscular blockade from muscle relaxants.

 

Option C. Carbachol:

 

  • Carbachol is a cholinergic drug that acts as an agonist at both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.
  • Carbachol is primarily used in ophthalmology to induce miosis or to reduce intraocular pressure. It is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine:

 

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It binds to nicotinic receptors and causes prolonged depolarization, which initially causes muscle fasciculation followed by paralysis.
  • Succinylcholine itself causes muscle paralysis and is used to facilitate intubation during anesthesia induction. It would not be used to reverse muscle relaxation; in fact, it would exacerbate it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the preferred agent for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a laceration on his arm sustained during a fall. He reports significant pain, and a local anesthetic is planned for wound closure. During the procedure, the patient becomes restless, agitated, and his blood pressure rises to 180/100 mmHg. Upon further questioning, the patient admits to using a substance recreationally that he believes is responsible for his symptoms. Which of the following local anesthetics is most likely causing his hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Cocaine

 

Explanation:

 

Cocaine is an ester local anesthetic with strong vasoconstrictive properties, leading to hypertension as one of its cardiovascular effects. Cocaine acts as a powerful stimulant of the central nervous system by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, thereby increasing sympathetic tone. This results in vasoconstriction, elevated heart rate, and raised blood pressure. Due to these potent vasoconstrictive effects, cocaine can induce hypertension, even at small doses, making it unique among local anesthetics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mepivacaine: Mepivacaine is an amide local anesthetic used for regional anesthesia with minimal cardiovascular effects. It does not possess significant vasoconstrictive properties and is unlikely to cause hypertension, making it a safer choice compared to cocaine.

 

Option B. Prilocaine: Prilocaine is an amide local anesthetic commonly used for regional anesthesia and dental procedures. While it is associated with methemoglobinemia as a potential side effect, it does not have significant vasoconstrictive properties and does not cause hypertension. Prilocaine primarily acts by blocking sodium channels in nerve fibers, reducing nerve signal transmission.

 

Option D. Procaine: Procaine, an ester local anesthetic, has a short duration of action and does not have the same vasoconstrictive or hypertensive effects as cocaine. It is primarily used in minor procedures and is considered relatively safe regarding cardiovascular side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a local anesthetic that causes hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects and central nervous system stimulation. It works by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, increasing sympathetic activity and blood pressure, distinguishing it from other local anesthetics that lack these effects.

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination, especially during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to follow proper procedures to avoid contamination and ensure the sample's accuracy. The best practice is to collect water from a gentle stream to avoid splashing, which can introduce contaminants from the environment into the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect water from already leaking tape: Not recommended as it could contaminate the sample and may lead to false results.

 

Option B. Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 2 minutes

 

Option C. Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: It is a good practice but this practice alone does not ensure the proper collection of the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text:
Which of the following drug is/are used for cyanide poisoning?

 

  1. Amyl nitrite
  2. Sodium nitrite
  3. Sodium thiosulfate
  4. Glyceryl trinitrate
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

For cyanide poisoning, the following treatments are commonly used:

 

1. Amyl nitrite: This is an inhalant that induces methemoglobinemia, which binds cyanide ions and forms cyanmethemoglobin, helping to detoxify cyanide.

 

2 Sodium nitrite: This intravenous agent also induces methemoglobinemia, which helps to bind and neutralize cyanide.

 

3. Sodium thiosulfate: This acts as a sulfur donor, converting cyanide to the less toxic thiocyanate, which is excreted by the kidneys.

 

4. Glyceryl trinitrate (commonly known as nitroglycerin) is not typically used for cyanide poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the options provided, the correct combination of drugs used for cyanide poisoning is: 1, 2, and 3

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: C. 1, 2, and 3

choices.text: Toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green
Carbol fuschin and methylene blue
Carbol fuschin and malachite green
Toluidine and methylene blue

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toluidine blue ‘O’ and malachite green

 

Albert stain is a type of differential stain used for staining high-molecular-weight polymers of polyphosphate known as metachromatic granules or volutin granules found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Metachromatic granules are also found in Yersinia pestis, and Mycobacterium species.

 

Albert stain is composed of two reagents:

 

  • Albert’s A solution consist of
    • Toluidine blue - 0.15 gm
    • Malachite green - 0.20 gm
    • Glacial acetic acid - 1 ml
    • Alcohol (95% ethanol) - 2ml

 

Dissolve the dyes in alcohol and add to the distilled water and acetic acid. Allow the stain to stand for one day and then filter. Add Distilled water to make the final volume 100ml.

 

  • Albert’s B solution consist of
    • Iodine - 2gm
    • Potassium iodide (KI) - 3 gm
    • Dissolve KI in water and then add iodine. Dissolve iodine in potassium iodide solution

 

Albert stain is basically made up of two stains that are toluidine blue’ O’ and malachite green both of which are basic dyes with high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. The pH of Albert stain is adjusted to 2.8 by using acetic acid which becomes basic for volutin granules as the pH of volutin granule is highly acidic. Therefore, on applying Albert’s stain to the smear, toluidine blue’ O’ stains volutin granules i.e the most acidic part of cell and malachite green stains the cytoplasm blue-green. On adding Albert’s iodine due to effect of iodine, the metachromatic property is not observed and granules appear blue in color.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is typically used in acid-fast staining (Ziehl-Neelsen stain) for mycobacteria.

 

Option C. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is not typically used for staining metachromatic granules.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is not specific for metachromatic granules and is not used in Albert staining.

 

Educational Objective

 

Albert stain, which contains Toluidine blue 'O' and Malachite green, is specifically used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. These granules are an important diagnostic feature for diphtheria.

choices.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.text: Brown Sequard syndrome is characterized by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome results from a hemisection (partial transection) of the spinal cord, leading to a distinct pattern of neurological symptoms:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Motor Function: There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
    • Proprioception and Discriminative Touch: Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Pain and Temperature Sensation: Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fine touch lost on the opposite side: Incorrect because fine touch is lost on the same side as the lesion, not the opposite.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature lost on the same side: Incorrect as pain and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option D. Only pain lost on the same side: Incorrect because pain sensation is lost on the opposite side and is associated with temperature loss as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemi section of the spinal cord involves the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Sequard syndrome.

 

 

Functions of tracts involved -

 

Fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus → ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception

 

Spinothalamic tract → contralateral pain and temperature sensation

 

Corticospinal tract → primary motor activity same side of the body.

choices.text: Cytotoxic T cells
B cells
NK cells
Helper cells

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cells

 

Cytotoxic T cells: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, typically derived from intracellular proteins, to cytotoxic T cells (also known as CD8+ T cells). When a cytotoxic T cell recognizes an antigen presented by MHC class I on the surface of a cell, it is activated to destroy the infected or malignant cell.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. B cells: B cells are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and by direct interaction with helper T cells (CD4+ T cells), not by MHC class I.

 

Option C. NK cells: Natural Killer (NK) cells do not rely on MHC class I molecules for activation. In fact, they often target cells with low or absent MHC class I expression, which is a common strategy of infected or transformed cells to evade cytotoxic T cells.

 

Option D. Helper cells: Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on APCs, not by MHC class I.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) For tubal ligation

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument shown is not used for ligating the uterine artery. Instead, instruments like clamps or ligature carriers are typically used for this purpose during a hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument is not used for ovarian cystectomy, which involves the removal of cysts from the ovary. Instruments like scissors, graspers, and cautery devices are commonly used in ovarian cystectomy procedures.

 

Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: This is incorrect. While laparoscopic instruments are used in the surgical management of ectopic pregnancy, the specific instrument shown (laparoscopic ring applicator) is not used for this purpose. Instruments used for ectopic pregnancy surgery include laparoscopic graspers, scissors, and suction devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The laparoscopic ring applicator (laparocator) is used for applying Falope rings during tubal ligation procedures.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acanthosis nigricans

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is the illness depicted in the image.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis rotunda

 

  • Description: This is a rare skin condition characterized by large, round patches of dry, scaly skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Melasma

 

  • Description: Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches, mainly on the face (cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip). It's often called the "mask of pregnancy."

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis

 

  • Description: An inflammatory muscle disease, dermatomyositis presents with skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash is often reddish or purple, seen on the eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, and sometimes the chest and back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 147, Page nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology 3rd edition Page no 391

choices.text: In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors
Upper third molar is most commonly absent in Mongolians
Prominent lingual ridge and labial ridge in mongols

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding teeth and ethnicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors

 

The cusps of molars are wide and deep and cusps of incisors are shovel-shaped is typically seen in Mongoloid races not in Africanoids hence the statement is incorrect. In Africanoids there is presence of large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

 

Option B), Option C), Option D): these statements are correct as explained in the core concept above. The question is asking for the wrong statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key differences between race

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuromyelitis optica

 

The most probable diagnosis is neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

 

NMO is a demyelinating autoimmune disease that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. Patients with NMO can present with recurrent episodes of optic neuritis, which can result in decreased visual acuity, as well as myelitis, which can cause weakness, sensory loss, and bladder dysfunction.

 

The patient's history of recurrent episodes of diminution of vision that recovers on treatment with steroids is consistent with optic neuritis, which is a common presenting feature of NMO. The history of transverse myelitis also supports a diagnosis of NMO, as myelitis is a common feature of the disease.

 

Management of acute attacks:

 

  • High-dose glucocorticoids
  • Plasma exchange.

 

Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses:

 

  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Rituximab
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Azathioprine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spastic quadriplegia: This is a genetic disorder affecting motor functions and does not involve optic neuritis or transverse myelitis.

 

Option B. Subacute combined degeneration: Typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency affecting the spinal cord, but not specifically linked with optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis (MS): While MS can present with symptoms similar to NMO, including optic neuritis and spinal cord involvement, the pattern of attacks and the severity of symptoms in the context of transverse myelitis point more specifically to NMO, especially considering the distinct pathophysiology and antibody profiles (e.g., anti-aquaporin-4 antibodies).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuromyelitis optica should be considered in patients presenting with recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, especially when there is a good response to steroid treatment. Distinguishing NMO from multiple sclerosis is crucial, as treatment and prognosis differ significantly between these conditions.

choices.text: COV of DBP is more than Vitamin D
COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability
It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.text: During your clinical rotations, you are reviewing data from an experiment that examined the correlation between Vitamin D levels and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). The experiment aimed to ascertain the variability within two distinct sample sets. Based on the findings, the average DBP was noted to be 110, with an associated standard deviation of 11. Similarly, the mean Vitamin D level was observed to be 18, with a standard deviation of 3. With reference to the coefficient of variation (COV), which statement accurately represents the collected data? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Coefficient of Variation (COV)

 

  • Is a measure used to compare relative variability
  • Is a unit-free measure to compare dispersion of one variable with another
  • Is SD expressed as percentage of mean

 

 

Calculation -

 

COV of DBP = 11/110 = 0.1

 

COV of Vitamin D = 3/18 = 0.166

 

Hence, COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The coefficient of variation provides a useful comparison of variability across different datasets.
  • In this case, the higher COV for Vitamin D indicates a greater relative variation compared to DBP, highlighting important considerations for researchers analyzing the impacts or associations involving these variables.

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Nephrogenic DI

 

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused by a mutation in the genes that encode for aquaporin channels, specifically Aquaporin-2. These channels are involved in water reabsorption in the kidney's collecting ducts. A defect in these channels impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine in response to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to the excretion of large amounts of dilute urine, despite the presence of adequate or even elevated levels of ADH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liddle syndrome:  Is characterized by gain of function mutation of ENaC channels causing HTN, Hypokalemia with metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Occurs due to mutation in CFTR membrane proteins.

 

Option D. Occurs due to mutation in Ascending Loop of Henle (Na-K-CL /Bertin/NA-Cl transporters).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

A mutation in the aquaporin channels, particularly Aquaporin-2, leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition is characterized by an inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine in response to ADH, resulting in the production of large volumes of dilute urine. Understanding the genetic basis of nephrogenic DI is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management, which typically involves addressing the symptoms and managing water intake rather than hormone therapy.

 

Reference - Harrison/Diabetes Insipidus/Chapter 381

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the esophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Image 3

 

The shows an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy. Barium swallow reveals an apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. The characteristic histopathological finding in this condition are nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 3.

 

In contrast to adenocarcinoma, half of squamous cell carcinomas occur in the middle third of the esophagus. Squamous cell carcinoma begins as an in-situ lesion termed squamous dysplasia (this lesion is referred to as intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ at other sites). Early lesions appear as small, gray-white, plaque-like thickenings. Over months to years, they grow into tumor masses that may be polypoid or exophytic and protrude into and obstruct the lumen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus typically occurs in the middle third of the esophagus and is characterized histologically by nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, as seen in Image 3.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1472, 1473

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of obstructive sleep apnea is scheduled for elective surgery. During the preoperative assessment, the anesthesiologist performs an airway evaluation using the Mallampati classification system. The patient is asked to open her mouth and protrude her tongue without phonating. Based on the visualization of the oral structures, the anesthesiologist classifies her airway as shown in the image. What is the Mallampati classification of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Class II

 

Explanation:

 

The Mallampati classification is a simple and widely used method to predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation by assessing the visibility of the oropharyngeal structures. In a Mallampati class II airway, the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible when the patient opens their mouth and protrudes their tongue. This classification suggests a relatively straightforward intubation but indicates that the airway may still pose some challenges. The image provided in the scenario shows the features characteristic of Mallampati class II, making it the correct classification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: In a Mallampati class I airway, the hard palate, soft palate, entire uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible. This represents the easiest airway to intubate, with no expected difficulty in visualizing the glottis during intubation.

 

Option C. Class III: A Mallampati class III airway is characterized by the visibility of only the soft palate and the base of the tongue, with the uvula either partially visible or not visible at all. This classification indicates a potentially more difficult intubation.

 

Option D. Class IV: In Mallampati class IV, only the hard palate is visible, with neither the soft palate nor the uvula visible. This suggests a significantly more challenging airway, often requiring advanced airway management techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is a valuable tool for predicting the ease of intubation based on the visibility of the oropharyngeal structures. A Class II classification, where the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible, suggests a moderately easy intubation, but with some potential for difficulty. Understanding this classification helps in planning for airway management during anesthesia.

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The structure given in the image is the incus.

 

The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. Head and neck of malleus lie in the attic. Manubrium is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.

 

The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.


Other Options:

 

Option A. The malleus is the largest ossicle and is shaped like a mallet. The parts of the malleus are the head, neck, handle (manubrium), and anterior and lateral processes. The head and neck lie in the attic.

 

The tympanic membrane is connected to the handle of the malleus.

 

Option C. The stapes has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of stapes in the oval window.

 

 

The joints between the ear ossicles are synovial joints. A saddle-shaped joint is present between the incus and malleus. Incus and stapes articulate via a ball and socket joint.

 

Options D. Vomer A facial bone forming part of the nasal septum, unrelated to the middle ear.

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It plays a critical role in hearing by transmitting sound vibrations from the malleus to the stapes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 9

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

A combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay can be used for the detection of Clostridium difficile.

 

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

 

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.

 

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins-toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plagues initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PC) or by culture.

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: C. difficile is an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture inappropriate and ineffective for its cultivation.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay alone: While sensitive, it lacks specificity for the detection of toxin-producing strains.

 

Option D. None of the above: There are effective methods, particularly the one described in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.

 

Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that contains many important tracts, including those for motor and sensory functions. Damage to specific parts of the internal capsule can result in different clinical presentations based on the fibers that are affected.

 

Posterior limb is the part of the internal capsule that carries corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions. Damage to the posterior limb can result in contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body). Therefore, a lesion in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule would lead to left-sided hemiparesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: This part of the internal capsule contains optic radiations, which are involved in visual processing. Damage here would lead to visual deficits rather than motor or sensory deficits.

 

Option B. Sublentiform: This part carries auditory radiations and is involved in hearing. Damage to this part would result in auditory deficits, not motor weakness.

 

Option C. Anterior limb: This part of the internal capsule contains frontopontine fibers and thalamocortical radiations, which are involved in cognitive and executive functions. Damage here might affect cognition but not typically result in hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following elements is not included in the provisions of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017, as per the WHO's mhGAP? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening of family members

 

  • The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 focuses on the rights and treatment of patients with mental illness, but it does not specifically include provisions for the screening of family members.
  • The Act covers various aspects such as the capacity to make healthcare decisions, advance directives, nominated representatives, types of admissions, bans on certain treatments (like direct ECT for minors and psychosurgery), decriminalization of suicide attempts, and regulations on restraints and seclusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mobilization of resources: The Act includes provisions related to the mobilization of resources for mental health services.

 

Option C. Social support: Social support is a crucial aspect of mental health care covered under the Act, ensuring that patients receive necessary support from family and community.

 

Option D. Interpersonal therapy: While specific therapies may not be explicitly listed, the Act does promote access to various mental health treatments, which can include interpersonal therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Screening of family members is not included in the Mental Health Care Act, 2017.

 

Additional Information

 

MENTAL HEALTHCARE ACT, 2017 (MHCA 2017)

 

  • Deals with rights of patients with mental illness and treatment delivery. Important clauses-

 

A. Capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision- Every person, including patients with mental illness, are assumed to have it if they can-

 

  • Can understand the information provided to them
  • Understand the consequences of their decisions
  • Can communicate their decision

 

B. Advance directive- Every person (not a minor) can make an advance directive in which he can mention-

 

  • How they wish to be treated/not treated for a mental illness
  • Applicable only if a person loses the capacity to take mental healthcare or treatment decisions
  • Duty of psychiatrist (or medical officer) to give treatment according to the advance directive
  • Doctor is not liable in case of unforeseen consequences while following the advance directive

 

C. Nominated representative (NR)-

 

  • Every person can appoint a nominated representative
  • In case of loss of capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision, NR would help in taking decisions about treatment

 

D. Admission- MHCA 2017 allows two types of admissions

 

  • Independent admissions- When the patient himself wants to get admitted
  • Supported admission (for a maximum of 30 days)- A person who has lost the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions and requires significant support from a nominated representative can be admitted under a “supported admission”

 

E. Ban on direct ECT

 

F. Ban on ECT for minors

 

G. Ban on psychosurgery

 

H. Decriminalisation of suicide attempt - Any person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be under severe stress and should not be tried or punished

 

I. Restraints and seclusions - A patient can be physically restrained only-

 

  • If it is the only way to prevent harm to self or others
  • If authorised by a psychiatrist in charge

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with total ophthalmoplegia, pulsatile proptosis of the right eye, retroorbital pain accompanied with fever and headache. On examination, fundus and BP were normal. Which of the following structures are involved?

 

  1. Abducens nerve
  2. Oculomotor nerve
  3. Internal carotid artery
  4. Cavernous sinus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The clinical presentation of pulsatile proptosis, retroorbital pain, fever, and headache in a pregnant woman suggests the involvement of multiple cranial structures, primarily those associated with the cavernous sinus, a critical venous sinus at the base of the brain that acts as a conduit for venous blood drainage from the brain and eye. This constellation of symptoms and signs is indicative of cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST), a severe and potentially life-threatening condition.

 

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a septic thrombus formed in the cavernous sinus due to the spread of infection from sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face.
  • Symptoms include fever, severe headache, supraorbital pain, seizures, and edema in the mastoid region.
  • Eye signs include proptosis, chemosis, and diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia from the involvement of oculomotor (CN-III), trochlear (CN-IV), and abducens nerve (CN-VI).
  • Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (CN-V1)
  • Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex due to oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Pulsatile proptosis occurs with the involvement of the internal carotid artery.
  • Brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently for diagnosis.
  • Management of CST includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants.

 

 

Educational Objective:

Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
