Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

 

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When writing a prescription, always avoid abbreviations for dosage instructions, use clear and complete language, include leading zeros for dosages less than one, and avoid trailing zeros. The correct format ensures clarity and safety for the patient.

choices.text: Block sodium channels
Block potassium channels
Block calcium channels
Block chloride channels

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Block sodium channels

 

  • Mechanism: Local anesthetics primarily act by blocking the sodium channels bound to the membrane of the nerve, thus inhibiting sodium influx into the nerve and avoiding depolarization of the nerve.
  • States of Sodium Channels: The voltage-gated sodium channels exist in three states:
    • Resting (non-conducting)
    • Open (conducting)
    • Inactivated (non-conducting)
  • Affinity: Local anesthetics have maximum affinity for the sodium channels in the inactivated state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Block potassium channels:

Blocking potassium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Potassium channels are more involved in the repolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Option C. Block calcium channels:

Blocking calcium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Calcium channels are more involved in neurotransmitter release at synapses.

 

Option D. Block chloride channels:

Blocking chloride channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Chloride channels are typically associated with inhibitory neurotransmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871

questions.text: Match the following E. coli with their respective pathogenesis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

1. ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.
  • Match: A. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.

 

2. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Invades intestinal mucosal cells.
  • Match: B. Invades intestinal mucosal cells.

 

3. EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.
  • Match: C. Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.

 

4. EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.
  • Match: D. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Direct stimulation of acetylcholine receptors
Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase at the synaptic cleft
Competitive inhibition of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction
Activation of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is undergoing an elective hip replacement surgery. During anesthesia induction, a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant is administered to facilitate intubation and surgical access. Shortly after administration, the patient develops profound muscle relaxation and paralysis without any muscle fasciculations. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the muscle relaxant used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Competitive inhibition of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction

 

Explanation:

 

Curare group muscle relaxants, such as atracurium and rocuronium, are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents. These drugs work by competitively binding to acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction without activating them, thereby preventing acetylcholine from binding to these receptors. This inhibition blocks the action of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis and relaxation. Since these agents do not depolarize the muscle membrane, they do not cause initial muscle contractions (fasciculations), making them useful during surgeries requiring controlled muscle relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct stimulation of acetylcholine receptors: This mechanism describes the action of depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents like succinylcholine, which initially cause muscle contractions before leading to paralysis. This is not the mechanism of curare group drugs, which are non-depolarizing.

 

Option B. Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase at the synaptic cleft: Inhibiting acetylcholinesterase increases acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, enhancing muscle contraction, which is the opposite of muscle relaxation. This action is seen with agents like neostigmine, used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Activation of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum: This action describes drugs like dantrolene, which is used to treat malignant hyperthermia by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, thus preventing muscle contraction. It does not describe the mechanism of curare-like drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curare group muscle relaxants are non-depolarizing agents that competitively inhibit acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, preventing acetylcholine binding and resulting in muscle paralysis without initial contractions. This mechanism is crucial for inducing controlled muscle relaxation during surgical procedures.

questions.text: Which drug is used as a first line management for postmenopausal female with osteoporosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases (pyrophosphate analogs) bind to the surface of hydroxyapatite crystals and inhibits resorption.
  • These drugs are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine.
  • Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss (as occurs with estrogen replacement therapy).
  • These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures.
  • These are the drugs of choice in postmenopausal osteoporotic females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raloxifene. Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) act as estrogen antagonist in breast tissue and as an agonist in bone. Raloxifene selectively stimulates estrogen receptor in bone and is used in treatment of osteoporosis. It reduces risk of breast cancer also.

 

Option C. Estrogen. Hormone replacement therapy is the mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis with estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Combined OC pills. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs) alleviate climacteric symptoms and might have a positive effect on BMD. Of note, progestin is the dominant component over estrogen in COCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first line drugs or drugs of choice to treat osteoporosis in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: A woman presents to you with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lupus nephritis

 

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems. The patient's symptoms of fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue, combined with new-onset hematuria and findings of RBC casts and proteinuria in the urine, are indicative of systemic involvement typical of lupus nephritis.

 

Lupus nephritis is characterized by inflammation of the kidneys, often leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and renal impairment.

 

Next Step -

 

Conducting an ANA (antinuclear antibody) test.

 

Performing an anti-dsDNA (anti-double stranded DNA) test, which is noted as being very specific and correlates with lupus nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: This condition typically presents with WBC casts rather than RBC casts in the urine and is not usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, or ulcers.

 

Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): While PSGN can cause RBC casts and proteinuria, it is generally a renal-limited condition and does not present with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, and ulcers.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is also a renal-limited condition and typically does not present with systemic symptoms. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually following upper respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus nephritis should be suspected in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus who present with renal symptoms such as hematuria and proteinuria, especially when accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue. Further testing, including ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies, is warranted to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Crohn’s disease in comparison to ulcerative colitis is least likely to show which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continuous involvement of the gut

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), but they have distinct pathological and clinical features.

 

Key Features of Crohn's Disease:

 

  • Segmental involvement: Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, segmental involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, known as "skip lesions." This contrasts with ulcerative colitis, which typically involves continuous, uninterrupted inflammation of the colon.

 

Continuous Involvement of the Gut:

 

This feature is typical of ulcerative colitis, where the inflammation is continuous and starts from the rectum extending proximally in a continuous manner without skipping any areas. In Crohn's disease, the inflammation is discontinuous, with normal areas interspersed between inflamed regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced risk of colon cancer: This is true for Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, as the risk of progression to malignancy is generally lower, especially for non-colonic Crohn's.

 

Option C. Higher risk of perianal fistula: Crohn's disease has a higher risk of perianal complications, including fistulas, due to the transmural nature of its inflammation.

 

Option D. Rarely present with daily hematochezia: Daily hematochezia is less common in Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, which is more likely to cause continuous bloody diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Continuous involvement of the gut is least likely to be associated with Crohn's disease, which is characterized by segmental, patchy inflammation known as "skip lesions."

 

Key Differences Between Crohn’s Disease & Ulcerative Colitis:

questions.text: A child presents with bilateral proptosis. Which investigation will help you in arriving at a diagnosis of chloroma? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peripheral smear

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localized tumor forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumor is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The best investigation among the given options would be a peripheral blood smear which shows the following-

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: While platelet count can be abnormal in AML, it is not the primary diagnostic tool for chloroma.

 

Option C. Hb concentration: Hemoglobin concentration might be reduced in AML due to anemia, but it is not specific for diagnosing chloroma.

 

Option D. Leucocytic count: Leukocyte count can be elevated, normal, or low in AML, but it does not specifically help diagnose chloroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peripheral blood smear is the key investigation to diagnose chloroma, revealing the presence of myeloblasts, which are indicative of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortan pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, page no - 1154

choices.text: Sertoli cell only syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Benign testicular neoplasm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sertoli cell only syndrome:
    • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
    • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
    • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.

 

Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm: Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Option D. Orchitis: Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

choices.text: It is approved for treatment of absent seizures
Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding lithium is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

 

Lithium is a commonly used medication for the treatment of bipolar disorder, but it can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. The tremors are generally mild and not a significant side effect for most patients, but in some cases, they can be bothersome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is approved for treatment of absent seizures: This is incorrect. Lithium is not used for the treatment of absent seizures. It is primarily used in the management of bipolar disorder and sometimes for treatment-resistant depression.

 

Option C. It does not cause teratogenicity: This is incorrect. Lithium can cause teratogenic effects, particularly if used during the first trimester of pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of cardiac anomalies, such as Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Option D. It is not absorbed orally: This is incorrect. Lithium is well absorbed orally and reaches peak plasma concentrations within a few hours of ingestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium, a medication commonly used for bipolar disorder, can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. It is well absorbed orally and has teratogenic potential, making it important to use with caution in pregnant women.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proprioception

 

Explanation:

 

Proprioception refers to the sense of the relative position of body parts and the strength of effort being employed in movement. It provides the brain with information about limb position, movement, and force. It is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temperature: Temperature sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive differences in external and internal temperatures.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve plays a key role in mediating temperature sensations from the face. It receives input from the descending or spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve for temperature sensation from the face.

 

Option B. Pain: Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus is responsible for pain sensation from the face. Pain fibers from the face descend along the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve and synapse in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Touch: Touch or tactile sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive pressure or contact with the skin.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: Light touch from the face is also processed by the spinal nucleus, but it's worth noting that discriminative touch (ability to recognize specific shapes and textures) from the face is primarily processed by the main or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei:

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

 

Positive axillary lymph node involvement usually indicates a higher chance of recurrence and a poorer prognosis compared to no lymph node involvement. The number of affected lymph nodes also plays a crucial role in staging the cancer, which directly impacts treatment options and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Generally, the larger the tumor, the worse the prognosis because a larger tumor size often correlates with a more advanced stage of cancer. Tumor size is considered when staging breast cancer, with larger tumors often requiring more aggressive treatment.

 

Option C. Distant metastasis: The presence of distant metastases (stage IV breast cancer) generally indicates a much poorer prognosis because it suggests that the cancer is more aggressive and widespread.

 

Option D. Hormonal status: The hormonal status of the tumor (estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive or negative) influences both the prognosis and the treatment options. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are often less aggressive and more likely to respond to hormone therapy compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of gallstones underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 2 days ago. He now presents with severe pain in the right upper quadrant that has been worsening since the surgery. On examination, a tender swelling is palpable in the same area. Further evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. Bile leak is suspected. Which diagnostic test would be most appropriate to confirm the presence of a bile leak in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP

 

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is highly recommended in cases of suspected bile leaks following cholecystectomy due to its dual diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities. ERCP allows for direct visualization and intervention in the biliary tree, where any potential leaks from the cystic duct or common bile duct can be identified and managed immediately. It can also facilitate the removal of retained stones or placement of stents to seal leaks, offering a swift resolution to symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRCP: While MRCP is useful for visualizing the biliary tract non-invasively, it cannot provide therapeutic intervention and may not be as definitive in the acute setting of a suspected leak.

 

Option C. HIDA: This scan is sensitive for detecting biliary leaks but lacks the capability for any therapeutic intervention. It is more appropriate for confirming the leak rather than managing it.

 

Option D. CECT: A CT scan provides excellent anatomical details and can identify fluid collections but is less specific for biliary leaks compared to HIDA or as actionable as ERCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational takeaway is the recognition of ERCP as the most suitable diagnostic and therapeutic tool for managing suspected bile leaks post-cholecystectomy, particularly when immediate correction is necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is measured by the device shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

 

  • Oxygen saturation (often referred to as SpO2) is the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to the total hemoglobin (unsaturated + saturated) in the blood.
  • The device measures this by non-invasively detecting the color change in blood as it binds oxygen.
  • The image displays a reading of "98%", which is consistent with an SpO2 reading. Thus, this option is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxygen content of the blood:

 

  • This refers to the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood plus any oxygen dissolved directly in the blood.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the total oxygen content of the blood. They only measure the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Partial pressure of oxygen:

 

  • Partial pressure of oxygen (often referred to as PaO2) is the pressure exerted by oxygen in the blood. It's typically measured using an arterial blood gas analysis.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure PaO2.

 

Option D. Amount of inspired oxygen:

 

  • This refers to the concentration of oxygen that a person is inhaling, often given as a percentage or fraction (FiO2).
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the amount of inspired oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulse oximetry measures the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of hemoglobin in the blood using the principles of Beer Lambert’s law and plethysmography.

choices.text: Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50

questions.text: Rituximab is a:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20

 

  • The suffix Mab implicates that it is a monoclonal antibody.
  • Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody against CD-20 which is expressed on the B-cells.
  • It is used in the treatment of B-cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20: Polyclonal antibodies are produced by multiple clones of B-cells and therefore recognize multiple epitopes. Rituximab is not a polyclonal antibody; it is a monoclonal antibody.

 

Option B. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50: This is incorrect because rituximab is not polyclonal and does not target CD50.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50: This is incorrect because rituximab targets CD20, not CD50.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the CD20 antigen on B-cells, making it effective in treating B-cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The specificity of rituximab for CD20 allows it to selectively destroy B-cells, providing therapeutic benefits in these conditions.

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

questions.text: An adult male patient in his 60s presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of haematuria. Upon examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass was observed, which was diagnosed as a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. What is the recommended course of action for this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

 

For this patient diagnosed with bladder carcinoma, transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the most beneficial treatment option among the given choices. Based on the available evidence, there is no indication of muscle invasion or advanced cancer, suggesting that the most probable pathological stage is pTa - low grade non-muscle invasive cancer, for which TURBT followed by intravesical chemotherapy is the recommended treatment. TURBT is performed to pathologically stage the tumor and determine the appropriate course of treatment. Intravesical therapy using chemotherapy or immunotherapy is administered after TURBT to eradicate any residual cancer cells in the bladder lining, but it is not effective against cancers that have spread to muscle layers.

 

This is the correct answer. TURBT is a standard initial procedure for diagnosing and treating visible tumors, especially for low-grade, noninvasive disease. It involves removing the tumor from the bladder wall via the urethra. The stage of the bladder cancer can be determined by examining the sample removed during a TURBT, which aids in further treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Resection with ileal conduit: This is a more invasive surgery typically used for muscle invasive bladder cancers (radical cystectomy). An ileal conduit is a urinary diversion technique where urine is redirected through a piece of the intestine and out to a stoma on the abdomen.

 

Option C. Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction: This involves removing a part of the bladder affected by cancer. It's reserved for select patients where the tumor is localized and not near the urethral or ureteral openings. It might not be the first line of treatment for a 2x2 cm low-grade tumor.

 

Option D. Neo-adjuvant chemotherapy: This refers to chemotherapy given before a primary treatment in advanced cancers. In the case of bladder cancer, neo-adjuvant chemotherapy might be used before a surgery to shrink the tumor size or improve outcomes. However, for a low-grade, small tumor, it is not typically the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy

 

Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit

questions.text: All of the following can cause miosis except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Belladonna

 

Belladonna is plant (Atropa belladonna) from which atropine (Anticholinergic drug) is obtained. It causes mydriasis not miosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphates: Organophosphates cause miosis by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, which increases acetylcholine levels, resulting in overstimulation of muscarinic receptors.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine induces miosis by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system through opioid receptors, leading to pupil constriction.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug that causes miosis by directly activating muscarinic receptors in the eye.

 

Educational objective:

 

Miosis or pin point pupil is caused by:-

 

  • Organophosphate poisoning
  • Opioids like morphine
  • Phenol poisoning
  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Cholinergic drugs like pilocarpine

 

Reference: KDT 8th/115,122,127,499

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After few months of treatment, he develops palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation. What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emtricitabine


Emtricitabine is an NRTI (Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor) which can lead to hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles.

 

Other options:


Option A. Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor. It can cause diarrhea or loose stools, dyslipidemia, lipodystrophy and hyperlipidemia.


Option C. Abacavir is an NRTI that can lead to Steven Johnson Syndrome.


Option D. Zidovudine is an NRTI that can cause nail hyperpigmentation, bone marrow suppression, myopathy, hepatotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine, an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV, is known to cause palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation as a side effect. This differentiates it from other antiretroviral medications such as nelfinavir, abacavir, and zidovudine, which have different side effect profiles.

choices.text: Mannitol salt agar
Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar
Sorbitol MacConkey agar

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli O157: H7? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

E.coli O157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, 0157:7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC 0157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

O157: H7 strains also are negative for -glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-B-glucuronide test. More than 90 per cent of other E. coli tests positive with this substrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol salt agar: This medium is primarily used for the isolation of Staphylococcus species because it contains high concentrations of salt, inhibiting most other bacteria.

 

Option B. Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar: Used for the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species, which are also important enteric pathogens.

 

Option D. CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) medium: Designed for urinary tract infections to inhibit the swarming of Proteus species and allow the differentiation of other urinary pathogens based on lactose fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sorbitol MacConkey agar is critical for distinguishing E. coli O157 from other E. coli strains due to its unique inability to ferment sorbitol, helping guide appropriate public health responses and treatment options during outbreaks of foodborne illness.
